Our group has a 3-course approach to game nights:
Appetizer: Something fun, simple, and short. Played while we're still waiting for everyone to show up. e.g. Splendor
Entree: One game of Twilight Imperium
Dessert: one or two new games that someone brought
It gives a sense of structure and reliability to know that we will *always* play a game of TI. About half the time, nobody brought anything new for Dessert, so we break out one of our faves from the collection. Usually Blood Rage, Game of Thrones, Star Wars: Imperial Assault, or Axis and Allies.

WRITING.TITLE: I was wrong about Donald Trump
WRITING.TEXT:
At first, I honestly thought he was running as a joke. "His campaign will never go anywhere," I said, add he rose in the polls.
"He'll lose momentum after the first debate," I said, as he killed it on stage.
"He'll never win a state," I said, as he took New Hampshire.
"He won't last," I said, as the field was narrowed to three.
"He can't won the primary," I said, as he did just that.
"The RNC won't let him be nominated," I said, as the delegates declared their votes for Trump.
"He'll be an easy opponent for Hillary," I said, as she was hammered with her email scandals, Benghazi, and more.
"It's a Hillary sweep," I said, as the voting began.
And then Florida went to Trump. Then Ohio. Then Wisconsin. Then Michigan. And North Carolina, and Pennsylvania, and suddenly I looked at the screen and realized that he'd won.
By my estimation, Donald Trump has performed a dozen miracles in the past year. He's defied conventional wisdom at every turn. He won the primary spending no money, running no ads, just speaking his mind. He won the presidency without every having held political office. Before he was even sworn in, he killed an extremely unpopular trade deal.
Now I hear people talk about more things Trump will never do. "He'll never build the wall," "He'll never impose term limits," "He'll never fix inner cities." And I think they're right. I don't think Trump can do any of those things.
But you know what? I don't trust my own judgement any more. When Donald Trump has committed to a course of action, he's succeeded. He's been right more often than I have.
So no more predictions. No more judging, no more condescending, no more "Trump can't" or "Trump won't." Because he's performed miracles this year. And when he says he's going to Make America Great Again? I believe him.

From my perspective, I used to hate netdecking because it felt like cheating. I mean, what's the fun of playing Magic if you're using someone else's deck? Where's the challenge?
Back when I was a wee casual player, I thought that the *game* of Magic was easy, and the real challenge (and fun) was in the *meta*game.
I still like the meta more than the game, but now I realize that actually playing Magic isn't just rules of thumb and simple statistics.

WRITING.TITLE: Interview for my first internship tomorrow. How should I prepare?
WRITING.TEXT:
Context: College Sophomore, majoring in CPE.
I've got a phone interview scheduled for tomorrow afternoon. The guy said he's looking for someone with "a reasonable object oriented development background" who wants to try "...a non-academic environment."
All my programming experience is academic. I'm taking an introductory C++ class, and in High School I took AP Computer Science (Java) and got a 5. However, I'm a bit rusty with my Java, since that was a few years ago.
How should I be preparing for this? Is it better to just review my old Java notes, or should I be doing coding problems? Thanks!

I don't deny that it's good, it just isn't format-defining. I don't internally groan when I see my opponent play t1 Inspector. It doesn't win the game on its own, just provides a lot of value for a low cost mana cost.
Ultimately, it's the kind of card that fits into almost *any* deck in *any* archetype. Whereas [[Smuggler's Copter]] and [[Gideon, Ally of Zendikar]] only excel in one or two archetypes.
Or maybe I'm wrong, and I'm underestimating [[Thraben Inspector]] because it's an innocuous 1-power 1-drop common. But I feel like it's not something you can or should plan against, unlike Gideon and Looter Scooter.

[[Thraben Inspector]] isn't too big of a deal. It's a versatile 1-drop common with lots of value, it can fit into any sort of deck that's running white.
[[Smuggler's Copter]] and [[Gideon, Ally of Zendikar]] have the potential to be format-defining though, and that's not good at all.

Yeah I actually have felt this way about a lot of girls, that I'm "narratively obligated" to crush on them. It's not something I'm uncomfortable with, it's just... weird, how my feelings are influenced so strongly by "what would make a good story."
Was your mutual friend "Cotton-eyed Joe"?

Four years ago, we went to homecoming together. I remember looking at her and thinking to myself, "I know exactly what this person is thinking right now. When she does something, I know *exactly* how she felt, what she thought, what went through her head as she did it."
We've drifted apart over the years, we're less similar to each other now. But I still crave that feeling of empathy, and I haven't found anyone else who even comes close to satisfying it.

Epilepsy, blood pressure, etc can all cause danger to the woman early on. There are medications, yes, but not all women respond to the safer ones. Pregnancy has also been known to make seizures more frequent and worse for women who already have them. For instance, I know a woman with epilepsy who has grand mal seizures frequently even though she's medicated.
And this is in direct violation of rule 1. Factual claims have to be supported with valid citations.

I was unfamiliar with this term. After a brief google search, I think it's probably fair to make ectopic pregnancy the sole exception to an abortion ban.
However, I'm still mostly in the dark about this issue, and I'd like to hear what /r/prolife knows about it.

The pro-life movement isn't generally in favor of exceptions for rape or health issues. The former is punishing the innocent child for the rapist's crime, and the latter just doesn't exist. By the time a fetus is big enough to cause health problems, it's viable and can be born via c-section.

None taken, I understand what you mean. But our adviser (the head of the Political Science department) suggested that we appeal to any relevant departments to get funding for the conference. Bear in mind that this *is* a debate team, and the topics for committees include the Center for Disease Control and the Women of the United Nations. Is it just that it works differently at different universities? Maybe some colleges will fund student activities, but others won't?

WRITING.TITLE: How much money do academic departments have to fund student activities?
WRITING.TEXT:
I'm a student at a large (30,000 undergrad) state school, and I'm looking for financial support for our Model UN team to attend a conference next January. Our faculty advisor suggested that we appeal to any relevant departments to get funding for the competition.
Problem is, we have no idea how much we should be asking for. The conference is going to cost ~$1,000 per delegate, and it's not feasible unless we can get department funding. How much can we expect to request/receive? Is $10,000 chump change for a big department in a big school, or is $500 a more reasonable amount to ask of them?
For clarity, we'll be asking every department we can. Poli sci, history, business, engineering, etc. Engineering is by far the biggest college at my school, and would probably have the most money to sponsor us with.
Please let me know if this isn't the right sub, and point me towards a more appropriate place. Thanks!
EDIT: There is a "Student Activities Fund" that pays for this sort of thing, but we've kind of reached our limit for how much funding they'll provide us. So we're looking for specific funding from academic departments to offset our costs.
EDIT2: We know how to sell it to the departments, tell them why they should financially support us, split the costs and ask different departments to front different costs, etc. I'm really just trying to figure out how much we should be asking for from each department. I have no idea how "department funding" works, as far as I know each department might not even *have* access to any funds. Or maybe they've got a million in grant money just burning a hole in their pocket. I don't know.
I run Long Tusk Cub and Empyreal Voyager as alt win cons. Cub has the massive benefit that you can pump him above a 4/3 if necessary.

I'm building Bad Infect (UG Electrostatic Pummeler) and the entire deck cost me about $20. It might not turn out to be the most competitively strong deck, but I figure at that price point it's worth a shot.
The deck is combo, and can pretty consistently win by turn 4-6.

If you're looking to build a cheap, competitive deck I'd recommend either aggro (WR Humans), or combo (UG Pummeler/UR Aetherflux Storm). Alternatively, you could look into mtggoldfish's Budget Magic brews. The ultra-budget versions are probably within your price range, and are often decent decks.
As for your question on the two paths you can take, just buy singles. It's never really worth it to buy anything else. Once you know what you're looking for, get a decklist together and order all the cards.

I was thinking that they should make the DOT *way* slower. Like, double the time it takes to kill. That gives enough time to use a healing ability so the ult doesn't kill you by itself. And it's more interactive, because getting hit by it doesn't just mean "you will die in 5 seconds and there's nothing you can do about it."

Fundamentally, it is a question of individualism vs tribalism. Black Lives Matter is a movement that wants to improve the situation of the black *population*, not necessarily black individuals. BLM holds *all* police accountable for shootings of unarmed black men. They hold *all* white people responsible for slavery and oppression. When they protest the shooting of a black man by a police officer, it doesn't matter whether the violence was justified or not, because what they're *really* angry about is the fact that black men don't have a good relationship with their local police.
The reason it outrages me is that this tribalist thinking goes against everything Martin Luther King Jr. stood for. BLM genuinely doesn't care about the content of one's character, only about the color of their skin.

**Magic Trick**
2UR
Sorcery
